posts.cooked: Both Slack and Facebook Messenger, perhaps others as well, provide the ability to “react” to a particular message with an emoji, which shows up next to that message. This would be a quick and easy way to respond to a message that may not be the most recent, but one in a set of messages. Sometimes a friend sends several messages (esp. pictures) deserving of different but simple responses, and an emoji reaction would be suited for this.

posts.name: mhartie
posts.cooked: I never thought such a feature would be useful until friends were using it in fb messenger with me. I now find it very useful. It makes it very easy to respond, especially in groups to statements such as: “who wants coffee?”, “pick you up at 9am”, etc. You can respond with a simple thumbs up or thumbs down. That is probably the ONLY thing I miss from fb messenger.

posts.name: Joshua Lund
posts.cooked:
You can do a similar thing with the new Quoted Replies feature.

signal-2018-05-02-152441.jpg1242×2208 255 KB

posts.name: Rolf
posts.cooked: Somehow I find it remarkable , that such a question receives an immediate answer from the signal team , while many other questions , which are important concerning security , remain without reply for a long time , or sometimes even forever.

posts.name: Joshua Lund
posts.cooked: I happened to see this one shortly after it was posted yesterday. I’m doing my best to keep up.

posts.name: mhartie
posts.cooked: Quote reply is a great new feature and I am already using it often. But for large group conversations it would be handy to have the same emoji as in fb messenger.

posts.name: Jason Tracy
posts.cooked:
Quoted reply doesn’t match the expectations many users have.
I have migrated people from GroupMe and Facebook Messenger, and the ability to see the reactions to a single post without filling the message log with messages is the missing link here.

If I ask “Who wants coffee?”, and everyone replied as you showed, it might be fine for 3 people. For 20, however, it is much better to look at a single post and the reactions to it without 19 responses that are scrolling the text.

While it may seem trivial, just the ability to “like” or +1 a post is really important to some users. I couldn’t believe how many grown adults missed the ability to “heart” a joke or comment when I moved them from GroupMe. Some were ready to move back because it wasn’t there.

While I get this doesn’t look like a security feature, it actually is: If I can’t get users to leave insecure apps, they’re completely exposed. Matching the user experience is important in order to get users off insecure apps, and I’m glad that Signal has recognized this.
Thank you!
Would love to see this feature for this exact use case! Happy to contribute as well.

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked: I think what @jlund was saying is that for now, quoted replies can sorta fill the gap. I’d bet this is something in the roadmap, but not the most pressing issue.

posts.name: Joshua Lund
posts.cooked: Yeah, this remains on the list.

jlund:

Yeah, this remains on the list.

This would be a great feature to have, I’m glad to see it’s on the list!

My opinion on such an ‘emoji reaction’ feature;
I think it may not be necessary because

  • ‘such a feature may not create notifications, so if somebody reacts to a message from a week ago I may not know about it until some time later when I go through my older messages. Therefore missing my opportunity to make a relevant response to the reaction. Such a reaction may also possibly never be seen if an older message with the reaction is automatically deleted.’
    The paragraph above may be based on assumption, missing experience or bad memory. I stand corrected.
  • such a ‘emoji reaction’ feature offers a limited number of reactions therefore not all users can fully express themselves due to its design. The ‘quoted replies’ feature on the other hand not only offers a wider range of emoji but multiple emoji in one response plus text and even file attachments and more. Therefore ‘quoted replies’ give the oppertunity for the user to fully express themselves and the one being replied to getting a potentially satisfying response. If the user chooses to give a single emoji reply using the ‘quoted reply’ feature the one being replied to knows that such a short reply is a result of choice by the user and not because of limitations in the ‘quoted reply’ design which are present in the ‘emoji reactions’ feature. Also using the ‘quoted replies’ feature removes the need for responding twice (the first emoji reaction, and a second quoted reply response). The ‘emoji reaction’ feature allows the user to give a short and potentionally less satisfactory response and partly blame it on its design.
    My conclusion;
    Such a feature is great for group messages with a lot of users, but there are some flaws in its general design that must be adressed aswell if ever it will be implemented.
That’s a really good idea as a stopgap; thanks!!

Junkii:

such a feature may not create notifications

Why wouldn’t it create notifications? Perhaps if a message was deleted there might be some difficulties, but in general notifications should work.

Quoted reply is a very useful feature, but I don’t agree that it’s existence makes reactions unnecessary. Reactions allow people to respond to a message that only requires a simple vote, for example, I could ask a large group chat “if you want pizza react with a thumbs up”. With reactions I just have to look at my previous message and read the number next to the thumbs up icon. Quoted reply would require scrolling through and counting all the individual replies which may have multiple other non-related messages between them from other conversation.

Think of reactions like the heart/like feature on this forum. We already have the ability to quote posts in a reply, but the like reaction is a very much useful feature on its own.

Such a feature is not available on Whatsapp, although it is available on Facebook Messenger, and I do not remember getting any notifications from such reactions on Facebook Messenger. I don’t know about other services, and perhaps my my memory is faded, but if someone could post a sceenshot of a notification from such a reaction to help me imagine please do

Junkii:

I do not remember getting any notifications from such reactions on Facebook Messenger

Messenger notifies you if someone reacts to your message.

In my group of friends I’ve gotten my male friends to use Signal despite limitations like this but I’m sure their wives wouldn’t like Signal because in our group chat on FB Messenger we make HEAVY use of reactions. Hoping this comes sooner rather than later because I’d love to drop my use of Messenger!

posts.name: Jeremy
posts.cooked:
haffenloher:

Messenger notifies you if someone reacts to your message.

Plus the emoji replies are analogous to replies by text I think.
Notifications only go to the person who wrote the message that got the reaction(s), not the whole group.

Junkii:

if someone could post a sceenshot of a notification from such a reaction to help me imagine please do

accepted_answer.excerpt:
Has now been expanded in Android 4.61 to include reactions with any Emoji:

Beta feedback for the upcoming Android 4.61 release

★ Stop feeling Emojionally unavailable. Now you can react to messages with any Emoji. Use to wave back when someone new says hello in your group chat, a cricket if nobody laughs at a joke, or fire for a particularly hot take. The choice is yours.

And here it is for iOS 3.10:

Beta feedback for the upcoming iOS 3.10 release

Feeling Emojionally unavailable? Now you can react to messages with any Emoji. Use to wave back when someone new says hello in your group chat, a cricket if nobody laughs at a joke, or fire for a particularly hot take. The choice is yours.

And here it is for Desktop 1.34.2: Release v1.34.2 · signalapp/Signal-Desktop · GitHub
